content.text: Buildings and structures in Lincoln Center:
Clark Studio Theater; Samuel B. and David Rose Building; Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse; [[LINK|lang_en|Walter_Reade_Theater|Walter Reade Theater]]
Claire Tow Theater; Lincoln Center Theater; LCT3 Theater; Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater; [[LINK|lang_en|Vivian_Beaumont_Theater|Vivian Beaumont Theater]]
Bruno Walter Auditorium; [[LINK|lang_en|New_York_Public_Library_for_the_Performing_Arts|New York Public Library for the Performing Arts]]

items.text: The **Film Society of Lincoln Center**, known since April 29, 2019 as **Film at Lincoln Center**,[[CITE|1|https://www.nytimes.com/2019/04/28/movies/film-society-lincoln-center.html]] is a film presentation organization based in [[LINK|lang_en|New_York_City|New York City]], [[LINK|lang_en|United_States|United States]]. Founded in 1969 by three [[LINK|lang_en|Lincoln_Center|Lincoln Center]] executives—[[LINK|lang_en|William_F._May|William F. May]], [[LINK|lang_en|Martin_E._Segal|Martin E. Segal]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Schuyler_G._Chapin|Schuyler G. Chapin]][[CITE|2|https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/21/business/william-f-may-95-dies-helped-found-lincoln-center-film-society.html?_r=1]]—the film society spotlights American independent cinema and world cinema, and recognizes and supports new filmmakers.[[CITE|3|https://www.filmlinc.org/about-us/]] The Film Society of Lincoln Center is one of the eleven resident organizations at the [[LINK|lang_en|Lincoln_Center_for_the_Performing_Arts|Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts]].

Over the last four decades, the [[LINK|lang_en|Film_society|film society]] has introduced to American audiences the works of many of the world's most acclaimed filmmakers, including [[LINK|lang_en|Fran%C3%A7ois_Truffaut|François Truffaut]], [[LINK|lang_en|Rainer_Werner_Fassbinder|Rainer Werner Fassbinder]], [[LINK|lang_en|Jean-Luc_Godard|Jean-Luc Godard]], [[LINK|lang_en|Pedro_Almod%C3%B3var|Pedro Almodóvar]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Martin_Scorsese|Martin Scorsese]].

Each year the organization presents its annual Gala Tribute, honoring legendary stars and industry leaders at Lincoln Center’s [[LINK|lang_en|David_Geffen_Hall|David Geffen Hall]], formerly known as [[LINK|lang_en|Avery_Fisher_Hall|Avery Fisher Hall]].

The Film Society of Lincoln Center also hosts the annual [[LINK|lang_en|New_York_Film_Festival|New York Film Festival]] and is a co-presenter (with [[LINK|lang_en|The_Museum_of_Modern_Art|the Museum of Modern Art]]) of the [[LINK|lang_en|New_Directors/New_Films_Festival|New Directors/New Films Festival]]. The Film Society also publishes the bi-monthly film journal *[[LINK|lang_en|Film_Comment|Film Comment]]*.

caption.text: The Film Society of Lincoln Center is located at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts in New York City

[[LINK|lang_en|Avery_Fisher_Hall|Avery Fisher Hall]], now called [[LINK|lang_en|David_Geffen_Hall|David Geffen Hall]] since September 2015, at Lincoln Center, where the Film Society annually held its Gala Tribute.
